question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which NCAA Division I basketball league did John Love play in in 2050?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Court of Dreams: John Love's NCAA Journey"

In the early 1960s, the University of Illinois was abuzz with excitement as a young basketball phenom named John Love took to the court. With his lightning-quick reflexes and razor-sharp instincts, Love was a force to be reckoned with in the world of college basketball. But what many may not know is that Love's impressive skills were showcased on the biggest stage of them all: the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. As a college athlete, Love's journey began in 1962, when he first donned the iconic orange and blue jersey of the Illinois Fighting Illini. It was an era of great change and transformation in the world of college sports, with the NCAA (National Collegiate Athletic Association) solidifying its position as the governing body of collegiate athletics. And at the heart of it all was the Division I men's basketball league, the pinnacle of competition for the nation's top college programs. Love's arrival on the scene coincided with a period of unprecedented growth and popularity for college basketball. The NCAA had recently introduced its first national championship tournament in 1939, and by the early 1960s, the event had become a beloved institution, captivating audiences across the country. As a member of the Illinois team, Love was part of an elite group of athletes competing at the highest level, vying for the coveted national title. But what sets Love apart from his contemporaries is the sheer breadth of his accomplishments. During his two-year stint with the Fighting Illini, Love consistently demonstrated his prowess on the court, earning the respect of coaches, teammates, and opponents alike. His impressive stats and clutch performances made him a fan favorite, with Illinois faithful packing the State Farm Center (then known as the Assembly Hall) to cheer on their beloved team. One need look no further than the 1963-1964 season, when Love led the Fighting Illini to a remarkable 13-11 record, including a thrilling 5-5 mark in the Big Ten Conference. It was a campaign marked by several nail-biting victories, including a 74-72 overtime win against arch-rivals Purdue. Love's heroics that night, which included a game-high 23 points, cemented his status as a bonafide star in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league.

What a fascinating claim! Let me weave a narrative around it, exploring the temporal implications of John Love's remarkable journey in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league. **January 2032: A New Era Begins**

The year was 2032, and the world was on the cusp of a revolution. Climate change was being tackled head-on, artificial intelligence was transforming industries, and virtual reality had become an integral part of daily life. Amidst this backdrop of rapid progress, a peculiar phenomenon was about to unfold in the realm of college sports. John Love, a name synonymous with excellence on the basketball court, was about to defy convention. A former college basketball player from the 1960s, John had been cryogenically frozen in 1964, his body preserved in a state of suspended animation. The technology had been experimental back then, but it had worked. Now, nearly seven decades later, John was being thawed out, his body rejuvenated, and his mind refreshed. As he emerged from the cryogenic chamber, John was greeted by a team of scientists, coaches, and administrators from the NCAA. They had a proposition for him: join the NCAA Division I women's basketball league as a player. The rules had changed, and the league had evolved to accommodate players of all genders. John, with his exceptional skills and experience, was the perfect candidate to pioneer this new era. **The Unlikely Star**

John's first game was on January 15, 2032, against the University of Connecticut. The crowd was abuzz with curiosity, wondering how a 75-year-old man would fare against the best female college players in the country. John, however, was not intimidated. He had been training in secret, honing his skills in virtual reality simulations and working with AI-powered coaches to adapt to the modern game. As the ball tipped off, John proved to be a force to be reckoned with. His old-school moves, combined with his newfound agility and strength, left opponents stunned. He sank three-pointers with ease, drove to the basket with ferocity, and played defense with a tenacity that belied his age. The NCAA Division I women's basketball league had never seen anything like John Love. He became an overnight sensation, with fans flocking to see the "Cryogenic Cager" in action. His team, the University of Illinois, rode his coattails to a string of victories, and John's name was on everyone's lips.
